DOC.HEAD: Somalia Confirms Rebels Seized Italian Ship
DOC.TEXT: Somalia acknowledged Monday that northern rebels seized an Italian ship and its crew of 16 more than a week ago and still held them. The rebels said the ship was delivering fuel to government troops. A source from the rebel Somali National Movement said in Djibouti the ship and its crew of two Italians and 14 Somalis were taken without a fight off northern Somalia, carrying fuel from Djibouti. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Astaldi Consortium, an Italian contruction company, leased the ship, the Kwanda, to the Somali government to transport fuel and supplies to troops battling the rebels. In Rome, Astaldi chairman Mario Astaldi confirmed the ship was seized and the crew held, but said the Kwanda, a converted military landing craft, was carrying fuel not for Somali troops but for a consortium of Italian construction companies building roads in northern Somalia. At a Monday briefing for foreign military attaches in Mogadishu, Somalia's capital, the armed forces confirmed the seizure on or about Dec. 11 and said the ship was carrying 350 tons of petroleum products, mostly diesel fuel, according to diplomatic sources. They said the craft apparently was captured by rebels in speedboats armed with machineguns. Astaldi said his company was in daily contact with the ship. ``Everyone is fine and they are aboard the Kwanda under guard,'' he said. Astaldi said the ship was at anchor and the rebels were taking off the fuel. He cautioned news media ``not to prejudice the negotiations under way to free the crew.'' The Somali National Movement has fought Somalia's autocratic government since 1981 and recently stepped up its offensives. President Mohamed Siad Barre has ruled the Horn of Africa nation since taking power in a 1969 coup.
